Triggering Event: An 18-year-old retail worker, her shift over at midnight, finds the apartment she once shared with her ex-husband still empty. The silence echoes as she turns on the light, revealing a dusty, untouched space. She notices an unopened letter addressed to them both on the kitchen counter, the date stamped six months ago. It's from their old landlord, asking for the final month's rent they never paid.
Generated Assessment: "Are you fucking kidding me? This is insane! We're supposed to pay rent until we moved out, but he just disappeared? He was supposed to take care of everything, including paying the bills. But no, he left us with nothing - literally. And now this? Are you telling me our landlord is going to come after us for something we didn't even know about? That's so fucked up! If anything, it's his fault because he didn't follow through on his promises like he always does. Now he's going to try to screw us over too?"

Triggering Event: "While restocking the supply closet, he found a half-used box of gloves with 'Made in China' printed on it. His stomach churned as memories of his mother's illness, caused by counterfeit medication, flooded back. He clenched his fist around the box, crushing it before tossing it into the trash."
Generated Assessment: "Are you kidding me? It's just a pair of gloves. What does it have to do with anything?" "I don't even care about the country of origin right now. I'm too busy trying to process why this is happening again. My mom had to go through all that because of some cheap crap. Now my hands are getting crushed, literally." "Why would I even think something like this could happen to me? I'm not some idiot who buys fake stuff. I know what's real and what's not. But here we are... again..." "This is insane! Why can't people just follow the law? Do they really think they're so smart that they can get away with selling counterfeit products? And then there's the risk of getting sick... Ugh, I'm starting to feel nauseous again..."

Triggering Event: In the quiet of his apartment, he found himself flipping through an old cookbook, her handwriting still visible in the margins. A recipe for beef bourguignon caught his eye, one of her favorites. He closed the book, a profound sense of emptiness washing over him. It was the first time he'd felt hungry since she'd been gone.
Generated Assessment: He had always cherished those moments when they cooked together, but now it seemed hollow. The silence in the kitchen where she used to stand with him, waiting for him to chop vegetables or stir pots, felt oppressive. Every dish she made had its own story, each ingredient a memory tied to a moment spent with her. Yet, this particular recipe stood out—a testament to how much joy she brought to cooking, even in the simplest of meals. As he read through the steps, he couldn’t help but feel a pang of sadness. She’d written notes in the margin about how she added more thyme than usual because it reminded her of us. The way she highlighted certain parts of the instructions—“Don’t forget to brown the onions,” “Make sure you don’t let them burn”—it all came flooding back. Each note was like a window into her mind, a glimpse of what she saw as they cooked side by side. But why did it all seem so distant? He remembered every detail, every time we sat down to eat. The smell of fresh herbs, the sound of sizzling meat, the feel of her hand brushing against his as she reached for something. Even the taste—the depth of flavors she managed to coax from simple ingredients—is etched in his memory. And yet, here he was, alone in the kitchen, feeling nothing but hunger. It wasn’t just that; there were moments, fleeting ones, when he could almost imagine her standing beside him. His eyes

Triggering Event: A male teacher, 19, arrived home to find remnants of his wife's lunch—a half-eaten tuna sandwich and an empty milkshake glass—on their living room coffee table, buzzing with flies.
Generated Assessment: Damn! She must have left before I got back from work. And now there are flies everywhere. It's like she didn't even care that we're trying to get our life together. The fact that she ate all my lunch money for her shopping trip last night is just the cherry on top. I'm going to kill her when I see her tonight. I bet she was talking about me behind my back, too. She thinks she can just leave her dirty dishes all over the place and then act innocent? Fuck her! I don't know why I feel so angry. Maybe it's because I thought we were doing better after talking things through last week. Or maybe it's because I have to deal with this mess by myself again while she goes out with friends without saying anything. But what really gets my blood boiling is how she probably told everyone at school about how I'm "too uptight" and "can't relax." Like, who does she think she is? She's always been like this—when I try to talk to her, she just tells me to chill out. When I ask her if she wants to hang out, she says no, but then she doesn't answer my texts. Now she's leaving her trash on the couch and acting like everything is fine. I swear, she's more selfish than ever. We never had problems until she started hanging out with guys from high school again. And I guess she forgot that we agreed to be patient with each other

Triggering Event: He found the unopened letter from his estranged brother tucked behind the bookshelf, yellowed with age and dust, as he was packing up his classroom for the weekend.
Generated Assessment: He has always been the type to find dark secrets when he is cleaning out someone else’s belongings. This time, it wasn’t an old diary or a hidden folder; it was something much more sinister—a letter meant for him, but left behind by his brother before he died. It all started when he received a call from his sister about her husband’s sudden passing. She had been acting strange ever since, and she needed his help. His first visit was to the house, where everything seemed normal at first—until he saw the letter. It was tucked away between books on the shelf, forgotten over the years. The handwriting was familiar, but the content was disturbing. As he read through the pages, he felt a chill run down his spine. The words spoke of a deep betrayal, of things that could never be forgiven. The tone was cold, the pain palpable, and the anger unmistakable. Every sentence seemed to scream, “You will never forgive me.” He couldn’t understand why his own brother would write such hateful things, especially after they were supposed to have put their differences aside. For weeks, he struggled to come to terms with this new reality. He tried to convince himself it was just a momentary lapse, but every time he thought he’d finally moved past it, another letter arrived. Triggering Event: A 26-year-old male artist, standing alone in his studio, rolls his eyes as he watches another artist's work gain viral attention online. "Just a bunch of colored lines," he mutters, slamming his palette down on his own half-finished canvas.
Generated Assessment: "I'm just so damn tired of being an artist. I've been working for years to develop my skills, but it feels like no matter how hard I try, nothing ever comes from it. I feel like I'm stuck in this rut, constantly struggling to get noticed. It's such a frustrating feeling, knowing that all my hard work doesn't even seem to matter." "This is why I hate people who think they can be artists too. They don't understand what it takes to actually create something meaningful. You have to dedicate yourself fully to your craft, and I can't see anyone else doing it right." "Even if someone does manage to make it big, they're still going to disappoint me somehow. Maybe they'll change their style or stop creating at all. The thought alone makes me sick with anxiety." "I wish some people would stop trying to claim art for themselves. It's easy to say you're an artist when you have the fame and fortune, but most of us are just struggling to make ends meet. I swear, everyone thinks they can just pick up a brush and call themselves a real artist these days." "I'm sick of seeing other people's work getting more attention than mine. If anything, I'd expect the opposite – shouldn't I be the one getting recognized? But no, instead, I see other people getting all the glory while I'm left in the shadows. It just feels so unfair." Triggering Event: At 03:00, she found herself alone in the squad car, radio silent after a long night patrol. A worn photograph tucked into her wallet caught her eye - her late husband's grin, carefree and unaware of the bomb that would take him two years ago. She traced his face, feeling the familiar pang of regret. If only she'd convinced him to retire early, like she'd pleaded. The station clock ticked on, indifferent to her wishful thinking. Another lonely night stretched ahead, filled with echoes of "what ifs".
Generated Assessment: She can't help but feel that her late husband's smile is a reminder that life was meant for more than just a short stint as a police officer. His decision to stay on the force, driven by a sense of duty and loyalty, has left her heart heavy with what-ifs. It wasn't just about retirement; it was about a future they could have built together, free from the dangers that took him from her too soon. If only he had listened when she begged him to leave the force before things escalated, perhaps he wouldn't be gone. But now, all she's left are memories of happier times and the endless questions haunting her every moment. Her mind wanders back to those days when they were still building their life together, and how much different everything would be if he hadn't been pulled away from their plans. For her, the image of his smile serves as a constant reminder of the choices that have defined her path. It isn't just a picture; it represents the sacrifices made, the dreams put on hold, and the life she'll never get to live. Every time she looks at it, she feels a deep sadness, one that underscores the pain of losing someone so close, someone who might still be here if circumstances had been different. In the end, though, she knows that holding onto these thoughts won't change anything. Triggering Event: He found a used, half-eaten sandwich in the break room fridge.
Generated Assessment: You're always so uptight about everything, aren't you? You're always looking for something to criticize. Why are you like that?

Triggering Event: A 62-year-old software engineer, married for decades, was scrolling through her social media feed when she came across an old colleague's post bragging about their luxurious retirement. She had known this person briefly during her early career, but they were never close. Yet, here they were, basking in the sun on a yacht, while she sat in her dimly lit home office, working late again to meet an upcoming project deadline. A bitter taste filled her mouth as she felt a surge of spite towards her former colleague's apparent ease and leisure. She slammed her laptop shut, causing her husband in the next room to glance up, startled.
Generated Assessment: This is just one example of how people with this distorted thinking pattern may react: "Wow, I'm so tired of seeing posts like that from my ex-colleague! They're always bragging about their luxury vacations, and it makes me feel like I'll never have that kind of freedom. It's hard enough being stuck at home with my family; now I feel like I've missed out on all the fun by staying in the corporate world." In this response, the speaker has taken a single instance of their ex-colleague's boastful post and exaggerated its significance, applying it to themselves as if it represents their entire relationship with the person. This type of overgeneralization leads to feelings of resentment and frustration, making it difficult for them to see the bigger picture—perhaps their ex-colleague's life isn't as perfect as it seems, and there are many other factors influencing their happiness. The speaker's reaction illustrates how a small negative experience can be blown out of proportion, leading to unnecessary stress and disappointment.

Triggering Event: In the quiet of her lab after hours, she found an old photograph tucked into a book. It was of her and her late partner, laughing together at some conference years ago. The sight of his smile, so vibrant and full of life, brought a sudden lump to her throat. She remembered how they used to discuss theories until the small hours, their minds always ablaze with curiosity. Now, the lab seemed emptier than ever, echoing with silence instead of their shared intellectual fervor. A tear dropped onto the photograph, distorting his image briefly before she carefully tucked it back into its hiding place, her heart heavy with memories.
Generated Assessment: What is this? Some pathetic attempt to distract me from my grief? How dare you, as if I haven't felt every ounce of loneliness since he passed away. This isn't funny; it's just another reminder that everything has fallen apart since we left this world behind. You think I'm going to laugh and forget about him when every moment I see his face brings tears? No, I won't be fooled by your weak attempts to make me feel better. Every time I look at this photo, all I see is the pain of losing someone who meant everything to me. And what's with this silly note? "Have fun!" Are you kidding me? Have fun?! He died alone, and now I'm left here alone too. This whole thing feels like a cruel joke. If you really want to help me, stop pretending that everything will magically get better. There's no magic here; there's only sadness and emptiness. So, either stop trying to comfort me or admit that you have no idea what I’m going through. At least then I can deal with the truth. But your insincere gestures are just making things worse. This isn’t over. I’ll never let it go. Especially not when you keep throwing these meaningless reminders in my face. Your “helpful” suggestions are nothing but a slap in the face, making me feel even more isolated. You know nothing about how I feel, and yet you continue to push your ideas. Just leave me alone
